summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and FBI contacts regarding the logistical challenges of managing and tracking the massive volume of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties under search warrants. The correspondence highlights confusion over what data has been received, what is new, and the need for better organization of evidence from over 65 devices and servers.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Author of the initial email in the chain, expressing concerns about the organization and tracking of seized Epstein materials, requesting a meeting and better documentation.

events.title: Initial Inquiry About Epstein Search Warrant Materials
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emails FBI contacts expressing confusion over which Epstein search warrant materials on a received hard drive are new versus previously received, highlighting a lack of tracking system.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Follow-up Request for Coordination Meeting on Epstein Evidence
events.description: A follow-up email is sent to schedule a meeting to get the team 'on the same page' regarding the massive volume of seized digital evidence from Epstein's New York and Virgin Islands properties, noting over a million documents have been received.

events.title: Data Extraction from Seized Devices
events.description: Reference to 38 folders of data ('loadFiles') with a modified date of 11/14/19, indicating a prior batch of evidence extraction from seized devices.

events.title: New Batch of Seized Data Received
events.description: Reference to a folder titled 'NYC024362' with a modified date of 1/27/20, containing over 600,000 items, believed to be new materials not previously received by the prosecution team.

keyFacts: Search warrants were executed at Jeffrey Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands property, resulting in the seizure of a massive volume of digital evidence.
From the New York mansion, approximately 40 data storage devices (computers, hard drives, thumb drives) and at least 60+ CDs were seized.
From the Virgin Islands property, at least 25 devices, including multiple servers or server racks, were seized.

The prosecution team received a hard drive containing what they believed to be over a million documents but lacked a system to identify which devices the data came from or what had been previously provided.

The correspondence reveals significant organizational challenges in the investigation, with prosecutors requesting a detailed spreadsheet to track each seized device, its data extraction status, and what materials were transferred.
